name: Flow statistics
functionStatement: Integrates the range of "typical" flows experienced by other processes. Examines the degree to which upstream infrastructure or land uses have fundamentally altered flow regimes (e.g., hydropeaking, dams, withdrawals).
descriptionMarkdown: Zero-flow days and dry periods quantify how often a stream is dry and for how long. Stable statistics indicate consistent flow duration; increases in zero-flow days in a historically perennial reach indicate alteration.
howToMeasureMarkdown: From daily discharge, count zero-flow days per water year and summarize consecutive dry periods. Use gage records or loggers/spot-flow notes and compare to historical or reference periods.

levels.label: Strongly Disagree
levels.criteriaMarkdown:
Observation: Prolonged cessation shifts expected flow category.
Criteria: Extended dry periods effectively change flow class (e.g., perennial to intermittent).

levels.label: Disagree
levels.criteriaMarkdown:
Observation: New or longer dry periods restrict habitat for weeks.
Criteria: Noticeable increase in zero-flow days or dry-spell length that reduces habitat availability.

levels.label: Agree
levels.criteriaMarkdown:
Observation: Slight increase in zero-flow days without changing flow class.
Criteria: Minor increase in zero-flow days or short new dry periods.

levels.label: Strongly Agree
levels.criteriaMarkdown:
Observation: Zero-flow days and dry spells match historical pattern.
Criteria: Stable zero-flow counts and dry-period lengths relative to reference.
